content.webTitle: Sir Bruce: A Celebration review – didn’t they do well

fields.headline: Sir Bruce: A Celebration review – didn’t they do well
fields.bodyText: Would ITV have been a more fitting place for a big Brucie tribute, even if – Strictly speaking – he did end up at the BBC? Spot on with the actual venue, though. Like Sir Lancelot at Camelot, and Sir Alex at Old Trafford, Sir Bruce belongs at the London Palladium. It was practically home (even if Wentworth was his actual home; handier for the golf). Tess Daly, co-host when he lived, has to go it alone tonight, dressed in sparkly black to reflect the mood – sad, but also celebratory. It’s a glitzy and starry occasion as well. It was filmed last month on the eve of what would have been Brucie’s 90th birthday. He’s here tonight, though, in the spirit of the show, and in everybody’s hearts, of course. Adam Garcia, accompanied by the BBC Concert Orchestra, taps through some career highlights – The Generation Game, Play Your Cards Right, Strictly Come Dancing – alongside a dance routine that ends up with his strongman/Rodin’s-Thinker pose. Bruce was a strong man, and a thinker. Also a man of the people, says Tess. And here are some people – in Blackpool, Glasgow and Cardiff – to confirm it. “He made you feel like he was in the room with you.” “He had that aura.” “He was a national treasure.” And they too do the Thinker, or say: “Good game, good game.” Michael Grade says he was generous, loyal and hard-working. Michael Ball and Alfie Boe sing a medley of his Sinatra favourites. Ant and Dec say he made it look easy when it isn’t. More interestingly, Ant says Bruce used to get annoyed with contestants. Yes, he did! On The Generation Game. He would move them round, physically, then give the camera that look. Dec has got a photograph of the three of them on stage, he says, and he chokes up a little. There’s quite of a lot of that, choking up a little. Jon Culshaw’s on catchphrases, and didn’t he do … you know how he did. There’s more singing from Dame Shirley B, and words from Sir Elton J, Sir Lenny H, Sir Michael P and Dame Joan C. It’s like a modern day Camelot, a round table of light entertainment; each paying their respects and expressing their love for a recently departed knight. Sir Elton says it took Bruce far too long to get his knighthood. “We were all knocking on that door for him and eventually he got it,” he says. That’s how it works; those who have already it knock on the door – or the palace gates – until they open up and let Bruce in. Nice to see you, ma’am ... Sir Lenny has a nice line: “He was a force of nature blowing through my entire childhood.” It was the same for everyone and their parents and their children. Best is from the (as yet) unknighted Paul Merton, recounting the time Bruce came on Have I got News For You in 2003. Remember? Of course you do. “Well, it will be nice to see them, to see them …” said Brucie, about Saddam’s supposed weapons of mass destruction. And that was followed by a game of Play Your Iraqi Cards Right. “Eight of spades, deputy prime minister Tariq Aziz …” Brilliant. Interesting what Paul M says about Brucie being nervous before going on HIGNFY, as he wasn’t sure of what a slightly high-brow audience would make of him. He needn’t have worried, of course, it was the greatest episode ever. But these were in Brucie’s wilderness years, before the Strictly Come Back. He might have retired earlier and never had that brilliant final act. It goes to show how random it all is, and how much chance is involved. If Bruce Forsyth hadn’t become what Elton describes as “probably our finest all-round entertainer of all time,” you can imagine him as one of the people himself, someone’s grandad, the one who likes a joke and a sing and dance, has pinpoint timing and enjoys an audience. It was an extraordinary career: 75 years from Boy Bruce the Mighty Atom. He’s in the Guinness World Records for having the longest TV career of any male in the world. There are further starry memories, from Claudia Winkleman, Bruno Tonioli and Darcey Bussell, Len Goodman and Anton de Beke. Jimmy Tarbuck and Russ Abbott are quoted, as are Rosemarie Ford and Alesha Dixon, Gary Lineker and Alan Sugar. Brucie somehow supported both Arsenal and Spurs and got away with it. That’s a feat in itself. Lady Forsyth – Wilnelia, once Miss World, then the love of Bruce’s life – is here with a big thank you, for everyone. Then more songs, lights, dancing, keep dancing. A fitting tribute, I think he would have enjoyed it.
